sen.j: 王仁（わに、生没年不詳）は百済から日本に渡来し、漢字と儒教を伝えたとされる伝説的な人物。
sen.e: Wani (date of birth and death unknown) is a legendary figure who supposedly came from Kudara (Paekche) to Japan to teach Chinese characters and Confucianism.
Wani (date of birth and death unknown) is a legendary figure who supposedly came from Kudara (Paekche) to Japan to teach Chinese characters and Confucianism.
Wani (date of birth and death unknown) is a legendary figure who supposedly came from Kudara (Paekche) to Japan to teach Chinese characters and Confucianism.

sen.j: 実在したかどうかは疑問視される場合もある。
sen.e: Whether or not he really existed is sometimes questioned.
Whether or not he really existed is sometimes questioned.
Whether or not he really existed is sometimes questioned.

sen.j: 日本書紀では王仁、古事記では和邇吉師（わにきし）と表記されている。
sen.e: He appears as Wani in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and as Wanikishi in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).
He appears as Wani in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and as Wanikishi in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).
He appears as Wani in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and as Wanikishi in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 王仁に関しての記述が存在するのは古事記、日本書紀、および続日本紀のみである。
sen.e: Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued) are the only documents that mention Wani.
Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued) are the only documents that mention Wani.
Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued) are the only documents that mention Wani.

sen.j: それぞれの記述は以下のようになっている。
sen.e: His description in each document is as follows.
His description in each document is as follows.
His description in each document is as follows.

sen.j: 古事記によると王仁は百済から献上された賢者とされる。
sen.e: According to Kojiki, Wani was a sage who was offered by Kudara.
According to Kojiki, Wani was a sage who was offered by Kudara.
According to Kojiki, Wani was a sage who was offered by Kudara.

sen.j: 文：「百濟國 若有賢人者貢上 故 受命以貢上人名 和邇吉師 即論語十卷 千字文一卷 并十一卷付是人即貢進（此和邇吉師者、文首等祖）
sen.e: Original: In response to the order (of Emperor Ojin) to offer a sage if there was any, Kudara offered one called Wanikishi.
sen.cmt: 文献内オリジナル文とその訳文というペアですので、英訳した場合内容は後列と同一となります。
sen.e: Original: In response to the order (of Emperor Ojin) to offer a sage if there was any, Kudara offered one called Wanikishi.
Original: 百濟國 若有賢人者貢上 故 受命以貢上人名 和邇吉師 即論語十卷 千字文一卷 并十一卷付是人即貢進(此和邇吉師者、文首等祖)
sen.cmt: 翻訳者のコメントを受けて、後列にこの訳があるので、この場合はオリジナルの文のままにしました。

sen.j: 訳：百済にもし賢人がいるのであれば献上せよとの（応神天皇の）命令を受け、（百済が）献上した人の名前は和邇吉師（わにきし）という。
sen.e: Translation: In response to the order (of Emperor Ojin) to offer a sage if there was any, Kudara offered one called Wanikishi.
sen.cmt: 文献内オリジナル文とその訳文というペアですので、英訳した場合内容は前列と同じになります。
sen.e: Translation: In response to the order (of Emperor Ojin) to offer a sage if there was any, Kudara offered one called Wanikishi.
Translation: In response to the order (of Emperor Ojin) to offer a sage if there was any, Kudara offered one called Wanikishi.

sen.j: 論語十巻と千字文一巻のあわせて十一巻をつけて献上した（王仁によって『論語』『千字文』すなわち儒教と漢字が伝えられたとされている。
sen.e: It is said that he was offered along with 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) (it is believed that "Rongo" and "Senjimon," or Confucianism and Chinese characters, were brought to Japan by Wani).

It is said that he was offered along with 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) (it is believed that "Rongo" and "Senjimon," or Confucianism and Chinese characters, were brought to Japan by Wani).

It is said that he was offered along with 10 volumes of Rongo Analects and 1 volume of Senjimon (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) (it is believed that "Rongo" and "Senjimon," or Confucianism and Chinese characters, were brought to Japan by Wani).

sen.j: ただし、千字文は王仁の生存時まだ編集されておらず、この記述から王仁の実在には疑問符がつけられることも少なくない。
sen.e: Note, however, Senjimon had not been compiled yet during the time of Wani, and this quite often brings up the question whether or not Wani really existed.
Note that, however, Senjimon had not been compiled yet during the time of Wani, and this quite often brings up the question whether or not Wani really existed.
sen.cmt: Noteの後ろに that を追加
sen.e: Note that, however, Senjimon had not been compiled yet during the time of Wani, and this quite often brings up the question whether or not Wani really existed.

sen.j: 帰化した複数の学者が、『古事記』編纂の際にひとりの存在にまとめられたのではないかとされる説もある。
sen.e: There has been a theory that naturalized scholars were made into one figure at the time of Kojiki compilation.
There has been a theory that naturalized scholars were made into one figure at the time of Kojiki compilation.
There has been a theory that naturalized scholars were made into one figure at the time of Kojiki compilation.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、王仁は百済王の使者阿直岐（あちき）という学者の推薦を受け、応神天皇の招待に従って応神天皇16年2月に百済から渡来した。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Wani, a scholar, came from Kudara in February, 285, in response to the recommendation by Achiki, a scholar and an envoy of the King of Kudara, and also to the invitation by Emperor Ojin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Wani, a scholar, came from Kudara in February, 285, in response to the recommendation by Achiki, a scholar and an envoy of the King of Kudara, and also to the invitation by Emperor Ojin.

According to "Nihonshoki," Wani, a scholar, came from Kudara in February, 285, in response to the recommendation by Achiki, a scholar and an envoy of the King of Kudara, and also to the invitation by Emperor Ojin.

sen.j: 菟道稚郎子皇子の師となり、後に帰化した学者である。
sen.e: He then became a teacher of Imperial Princess Iratsuko UJINOWAKI and later became naturalized.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He then became a teacher of Imperial Princess Iratsuko UJINOWAKI and later became naturalized.
He then became a teacher of Imperial Prince Iratsuko UJINOWAKI and later became naturalized.
sen.cmt: 同皇子は男性なのでImperial Princess←Imperial Prince

sen.j: 「十五年秋八月 壬戌朔丁卯 百濟王遣阿直岐 貢良馬二匹 即養於輕阪上廄 因以阿直岐令掌飼 故號其養馬之處曰 廄阪也 阿直岐亦能讀經典 及太子菟道稚郎子師焉 於是天皇問阿直岐曰 如勝汝博士亦有耶 對曰 有王仁者 是秀也 時遣上毛野君祖 荒田別 巫別於百濟 仍徵王仁也 其阿直岐者 阿直岐史之始祖也 十六年春二月 王仁來之 則太子菟道稚郎子師之 習諸典籍於王仁 莫不通達 所謂王仁者 是書首等始祖也」
sen.cmt: 意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず
sen.e: '十五年秋八月 壬戌朔丁卯 百濟王遣阿直岐 貢良馬二匹 即養於輕阪上廄 因以阿直岐令掌飼 故號其養馬之處曰 廄阪也 阿直岐亦能讀經典 及太子菟道稚郎子師焉 於是天皇問阿直岐曰 如勝汝博士亦有耶 對曰 有王仁者 是秀也 時遣上毛野君祖 荒田別 巫別於百濟 仍徵王仁也 其阿直岐者 阿直岐史之始祖也 十六年春二月 王仁來之 則太子菟道稚郎子師之 習諸典籍於王仁 莫不通達 所謂王仁者 是書首等始祖也'
sen.cmt: 意味解釈が困難なため訳出できず
sen.e: '十五年秋八月 壬戌朔丁卯 百濟王遣阿直岐 貢良馬二匹 即養於輕阪上廄 因以阿直岐令掌飼 故號其養馬之處曰 廄阪也 阿直岐亦能讀經典 及太子菟道稚郎子師焉 於是天皇問阿直岐曰 如勝汝博士亦有耶 對曰 有王仁者 是秀也 時遣上毛野君祖 荒田別 巫別於百濟 仍徵王仁也 其阿直岐者 阿直岐史之始祖也 十六年春二月 王仁來之 則太子菟道稚郎子師之 習諸典籍於王仁 莫不通達 所謂王仁者 是書首等始祖也'

sen.j: 続日本紀によると、子孫である左大史･正六位上の文忌寸（ふみのいみき）最弟（もおと）らが先祖の王仁は漢の皇帝の末裔と桓武天皇に奏上したという記述がある。
sen.e: According to Shoku Nihongi, Imiki FUMINO, who was Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) Sadaishi (First Secretary of the Left), and Mooto told Emperor Kammu that their ancestor Wani was a descendant of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.

According to Shoku Nihongi, Imiki FUMINO, who was Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) Sadaishi (First Secretary of the Left), and Mooto told Emperor Kammu that their ancestor Wani was a descendant of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.

According to Shoku Nihongi, Imiki FUMINO, who was Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) Sadaishi (First Secretary of the Left), and Mooto told Emperor Kammu that their ancestor Wani was a descendant of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.

sen.j: このことから王仁は楽浪郡出身で百済にやってきた漢人の家系に連なり、漢高帝の末裔であるとされる。
sen.e: This led to the theory that Wani was from Rakuro County (an ancient county that existed in the northern Korean Peninsula), was a member of a Han family that came to Kudara, and was a descendent of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.

This leads to a theory that Wani was from Rakuro County (an ancient county that existed in the northern Korean Peninsula), was a member of a Han family that came to Kudara, and was a descendent of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.
sen.cmt: This led to the theory --> This leads to a theory
sen.e: This leads to a theory that Wani was from Rakuro County (an ancient county that existed in the northern Korean Peninsula), was a member of a Han family that came to Kudara, and was a descendent of the Emperor of the Han dynasty.

sen.j: この記述が真実であれば、王仁は313年の楽浪郡滅亡の際に百済へと亡命した楽浪王氏の一員ではないかと考えられる。
sen.e: If this is true, Wani could be a member of the Rakuroo clan that fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in 313.
If this is true, Wani could have been a member of the Rakuroo clan that fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in 313.
sen.cmt: Wani could be --> Wani could have been
sen.e: If this is true, Wani could have been a member of the Rakuroo clan that fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in 313.

sen.j: 楽浪の時代を通じて強力な勢力をもった楽浪王氏は斉（中国山東省）の出自といわれ、前一七〇年代に斉の内乱を逃れて楽浪の山中に入植したものという。
sen.e: The Rakuroo clan that had strong political power throughout the Rakuro area is said to have originated in the Qi dynasty (Shandong Province, China) and colonized the mountains in Rakuro after escaping from the Qi dynasty civil wars in the 170's.

The Rakuroo clan that had strong political power throughout the Rakuro area is said to have originated in the Qi dynasty (Shandong Province, China) and colonized the mountains in Rakuro after escaping from the Qi dynasty civil wars in the B.C. 170's.
sen.cmt: throughout the Rakuro areaを throughout the Rakuro era に変更、B.C.を追記
sen.e: The Rakuroo clan that had strong political power throughout the Rakuro area is said to have originated in the Qi dynasty (Shandong Province, China) and colonized the mountains in Rakuro after escaping from the Qi dynasty civil wars in the B.C. 170's.

sen.j: おそらく、3世紀前半の楽浪郡の滅亡後に百済へ亡命、その後、3世紀後半には日本へ移民したのであろう。
sen.e: Wani probably fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in the early third century and immigrated to Japan in the later third century.
Wani probably fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in the early third century and immigrated to Japan in the later third century.
Wani probably fled to Kudara when Rakuro County collapsed in the early third century and immigrated to Japan in the later third century.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島の人間が中国風の一字姓を名乗りはじめるのは新羅以降の風習で、当時の百済の人間が王姓を名乗っているとは考えにくい。
sen.e: It was after the time of Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) that people from the Korean Peninsula started to use Chinese-style one-character family names and it is not likely that people from Kudara at that time used the family name Wan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was after the time of Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) that people from the Korean Peninsula started to use Chinese-style one-character family names and it is not likely that people from Kudara at that time used the family name Wan.

It was after the time of Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) that people from the Korean Peninsula started to use Chinese-style one-character family names and it is not likely that people from Kudara at that time used the family name Wan.

sen.j: この点から考えても楽浪王氏であるという説は説得力を持っている。
sen.e: For this reason, the theory that Wani was a member of the Rakuroo clan is plausible.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For this reason, the theory that Wani was a member of the Rakuroo clan is plausible.
For this reason, the theory that Wani was a member of the Rakuroo clan is plausible.

tit.e: Wani in the Republic of Korea
Wani in the Republic of Korea
Wani in the Republic of Korea

sen.j: 元来、朝鮮には王仁伝承は存在しなかった。
sen.e: The legend of Wani did not exist in Korea.
The legend of Wani did not exist in Korea.
The legend of Wani did not exist in Korea.

sen.j: 現在は彼の地でも知られているが、これは近代になって流入した知識によるものである。
sen.e: It is now known there, but this is because information was imported in modern times.
It is now known there, but this is because information was imported in modern times.
It is now known there, but this is because information was imported in modern times.

sen.j: 大韓民国で王仁は日本に文化を伝えた『韓国人』として扱われており、中学生用の国定歴史教科書には「王仁は日本に進んだ文化を伝えた」と記述されている。
sen.e: In South Korea, Wani is considered as a "Korean" who brought his own culture into Japan, and government-designated textbooks for junior high school students state that 'Wani introduced advanced culture to Japan.'

In South Korea, Wani is considered as a "Korean" who brought his own culture into Japan, and government-designated textbooks for junior high school students state that 'Wani introduced advanced culture to Japan.'

In South Korea, Wani is considered as a "Korean" who brought his own culture into Japan, and government-designated textbooks for junior high school students state that 'Wani introduced advanced culture to Japan.'

sen.j: また、近年、全羅南道の霊岩郡では、毎年王仁博士祭りを開き、日本に文化を伝えた王仁を記念している（現在全羅南道には王仁関連の遺跡も存在しているが、1970年代以降に創作されたものであり、伝承地が作られてゆく生きた実例となっている）。
sen.e: In recent years, the Wang-in Culture Festival is held annually in Yeongam County of South Cholla Province to commemorate Wani who introduced advanced culture to Japan (there are also Wani-related ruins in South Cholla Province but they were created after the 1970's, and these are serving as good examples of creation of a legendary site).

In recent years, the Wang-in Culture Festival has been held annually in Yeongam County of South Cholla Province to commemorate Wani who introduced advanced culture to Japan (there are also Wani-related ruins in South Cholla Province but they were created after the 1970's, and these are serving as good examples of creation of a legendary site).

In recent years, the Wang-in Culture Festival has been held annually in Yeongam County of South Cholla Province to commemorate Wani who introduced advanced culture to Japan (there are also Wani-related ruins in South Cholla Province but they were created after the 1970's, and these are serving as good examples of creation of a legendary site).

sen.j: しかし、王仁は日本書紀、古事記、続日本紀にのみ記述され、韓国に残る歴史書である三国史記、三国遺事などの書籍には王仁、あるいは王仁に比定される人物の記述は存在しない。
sen.e: Note, however, Wani appears only in Nihonshoki, Kojiki, and Shoku Nihongi, and none of the historical books in Korea such as Samguk Sagi (History of the Three Kingdoms) and Sangokuiji Yusa (an Anecdotal History of the Three Kingdoms in Ancient Korea) mentions Wani or any other person who is identified as Wani.

Note that, however, Wani appears only in Nihonshoki, Kojiki, and Shoku Nihongi, and none of the historical books in Korea such as Samguk Sagi (History of the Three Kingdoms) and Sangokuiji Yusa (an Anecdotal History of the Three Kingdoms in Ancient Korea) mentions Wani or any other person who is identified as Wani.
sen.cmt: Note の後ろにthat を追記
sen.e: Note that, however, Wani appears only in Nihonshoki, Kojiki, and Shoku Nihongi, and none of the historical books in Korea such as Samguk Sagi (History of the Three Kingdoms) and Sangokuiji Yusa (an Anecdotal History of the Three Kingdoms in Ancient Korea) mentions Wani or any other person who is identified as Wani.

tit.j: 古今和歌集の仮名序に見る王仁の作とされる歌
tit.e: A Poem Considered to be Created by Wani Introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Preface of Kokinwakashu Written in Kana by KI no Tsurayuki)
A Poem Considered to be Created by Wani Introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Preface of Kokinwakashu Written in Kana by KI no Tsurayuki)
A Poem Considered to be Created by Wani Introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Preface of Kokinwakashu Written in Kana by KI no Tsurayuki)

sen.j: 古今和歌集の仮名序に見る王仁の作とされるこの歌は百人一首には含まれてはいないが、全日本かるた協会が競技かるたの際の序歌に指定しており、大会の時に一首目に読まれる歌である。
sen.e: A poem supposedly created by Wani introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo is not included in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets) but is designated as a joka to be read at the beginning of a karuta card competition held by the All-Japan Karuta Association.

A poem supposedly created by Wani introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo is not included in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets) but is designated as a joka to be read at the beginning of a karuta card competition held by the All-Japan Karuta Association.

A poem supposedly created by Wani introduced in Kokin Wakashu Kanajo is not included in Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets) but is designated as a joka to be read at the beginning of a karuta card competition held by the All-Japan Karuta Association.

sen.j: 歌人の佐佐木信綱が序歌に選定したとされる。
sen.e: It is believed that the poet Nobutsuna SASAKI selected Wani's poem as a joka.
It is believed that a poet Nobutsuna SASAKI selected Wani's poem as a joka.
sen.cmt: the poet Nobutsuna SASAKI --> a poet Nobutsuna SASAKI
sen.e: It is believed that a poet Nobutsuna SASAKI selected Wani's poem as a joka.

sen.j: なお大会の歌は「今を春べと」に変えて歌われる。
sen.e: In the competition, the wording of the poem is changed to 'Ima wo Harubeto.'
In the competition, the wording of the poem is changed to 'Ima wo Harubeto.'
In the competition, the wording of the poem is changed to 'Ima wo Harubeto.'

sen.j: 真偽は不明であるが以下に示す。
sen.e: Whether or not the information below is true is not certain.
Whether or not the information below is true is not certain.
Whether or not the information below is true is not certain.

Hirakata City, Osaka Prefecture

sen.j: 名称 大阪府史跡 伝王仁墓

sen.j: 経緯
sen.e: Details
Details
Details

sen.j: 1616年（元和 (日本)2年）、藤坂の山中にオニ墓と呼ばれる2個の自然石があった。
sen.e: In 1616, there were two natural stones called ogres' tombs on the mountain of Fujisaka.
In 1616, there were two natural stones called ogres' tombs on the mountain of Fujisaka.
In 1616, there were two natural stones called ogres' tombs on the mountain of Fujisaka.

sen.j: 歯痛やおこりに霊験があったとされた。
sen.e: These two stones were believed to miraculously cure toothaches or fevers.
These two stones were believed to miraculously cure toothaches or fevers.
These two stones were believed to miraculously cure toothaches or fevers.

sen.j: 禁野村和田寺の道俊は王仁の子孫と自称し、『王仁墳廟来朝記』を著した。
sen.e: Michitoshi of Wada-ji Temple of Kinya Village claimed himself as being a descendent of Wani and wrote "Wani Hunbyoraichoki."
Michitoshi of Wada-ji Temple of Kinya Village claimed himself as being a descendent of Wani and wrote "Wani Hunbyoraichoki."
Michitoshi of Wada-ji Temple of Kinya Village claimed himself as being a descendent of Wani and wrote "Wani Hunbyoraichoki."

sen.j: 藤坂村字御墓谷のオニ墓は王仁墓の訛ったものと表した。
sen.e: In his writing, he stated that the name Oni-bo, or ogres' tombs, in Ohakadani, Fujisaka Village, was a result of heavy accent on Wani-bo, or Wani's tomb.
In his writing, he stated that the name Oni-bo, or ogres' tombs, in Ohakadani, Fujisaka Village, was a result of heavy accent on Wani-bo, or Wani's tomb.
In his writing, he stated that the name Oni-bo, or ogres' tombs, in Ohakadani, Fujisaka Village, was a result of heavy accent on Wani-bo, or Wani's tomb.

sen.j: 1731年（享保16年）、京都の儒学者並川五一郎が上記文献により、墓所中央の自然石を王仁の墓とし、領主・久貝因幡守に進言「博士王仁之墓」の碑を建立。
sen.e: In 1731, Goichiro NAMIKAWA, a Confucian scholar from Kyoto, claimed based on the abovementioned writing that the natural stone at the center of the graveyard was the tomb of Wani, and proposed KUGAI, the landlord and governor of Inaba Province, to establish 'Dr. Wani's tomb.'

In 1731, Goichiro NAMIKAWA, a Confucian scholar from Kyoto, claimed based on the abovementioned writing that the natural stone at the center of the graveyard was the tomb of Wani, and proposed KUGAI, the landlord and governor of Inaba Province, to establish 'Dr. Wani's tomb.'

In 1731, Goichiro NAMIKAWA, a Confucian scholar from Kyoto, claimed based on the abovementioned writing that the natural stone at the center of the graveyard was the tomb of Wani, and proposed KUGAI, the landlord and governor of Inaba Province, to establish 'Dr. Wani's tomb.'

sen.j: 1937年、北河内郡菅原村村長が大阪府に史跡指定を申請。
sen.e: In 1937, the head of Sugawara mura, Kitagawachi gun applied to Osaka Prefecture for designation of the village as a historic site.
In 1937, the head of Sugawara mura, Kitagawachi gun applied to Osaka Prefecture for designation of the village as a historic site.
In 1937, the head of Sugawara mura, Kitagawachi gun applied to Osaka Prefecture for designation of the village as a historic site.

sen.j: 1938年、大阪府は申請に従い史跡13号に指定。
sen.e: 1938, Osaka Prefecture accepted the application and designated the village as historic site No. 13.
1938, Osaka Prefecture accepted the application and designated the village as historic site No. 13.
1938, Osaka Prefecture accepted the application and designated the village as historic site No. 13.

sen.j: 大阪府大阪市

sen.j: 名称 一本松稲荷大明神（王仁大明神・八坂神社）
sen.e: Name: Ipponmatsu Inari Daimyojin (Inari Daimyo-jin God of lone pine tree) (Wani Daimyo-jin God at Yasaka-jinja Shrine)

sen.j: 場所 大阪市北区 (大阪市)大淀中3丁目（旧大淀区大仁町）

sen.j: 経緯 王仁の墓と伝えられていた。
sen.e: Details: It has been said to be the tomb of Wani.
Details: It has been said to be the tomb of Wani.
Details: It has been said to be the tomb of Wani.

sen.j: また王仁大明神の近辺に1960年代まであった旧地名「大仁（だいに）」は、王仁に由来していると伝えられている。
sen.e: Also, there was an area called 'Daini' up to the 1960's near Wani Daimyo-jin, and the name Daini is said to come from Wani.
Also, there was an area called 'Daini' up to the 1960's near Wani Daimyo-jin, and the name Daini is said to come from Wani.

sen.j: 1968年 金昌洙来日
sen.e: 1968: Kim Chang Soo came to Japan.
1968: Kim Chang Soo came to Japan.
1968: Kim Chang Soo came to Japan.

sen.j: 1970年 金昌洙再度来日、王仁の資料収集。
sen.e: 1970: Kim Chang Soo revisited Japan and collected information on Wani.
1970: Kim Chang Soo revisited Japan and collected information on Wani.
1970: Kim Chang Soo revisited Japan and collected information on Wani.

sen.j: 王仁研究所を設立。
sen.e: He built the Wani Research Institute.
He built the Wani Research Institute.
He built the Wani Research Institute.

sen.j: 1972年8月 金昌洙、中央日報に『百済賢人 博士王仁』15回連載。
sen.e: August, 1972: Kim Chang Soo published the "Kudara Kenjin (the wise man of Paekche) Dr. Wan" series in 15 editions of Joong Ang Daily.
August, 1972: Kim Chang Soo published the "Kudara Kenjin (the wise man of Paekche) Dr. Wan" series in 15 editions of Joong Ang Daily.
August, 1972: Kim Chang Soo published the "Kudara Kenjin (the wise man of Paekche) Dr. Wan" series in 15 editions of Joong Ang Daily.

sen.j: 10月19日 姜信遠（霊岩郡青年会議所会長）の情報提供で当地生誕地と認定。
sen.e: October 19: Kim Chang Soo determined that Yeongam County was Wani's birthplace based on the information provided by Kyo Shin Ei (Chairman of the Junior Chamber in Yeongam County).
October 19: Kim Chang Soo determined that Yeongam County was Wani's birthplace based on the information provided by Kyo Shin Ei (Chairman of the Junior Chamber in Yeongam County).
October 19: Kim Chang Soo determined that Yeongam County was Wani's birthplace based on the information provided by Kyo Shin Ei (Chairman of the Junior Chamber in Yeongam County).

sen.j: 1973年2月 現地調査
sen.e: February, 1973: A field survey was conducted.
February, 1973: A field survey was conducted.
February, 1973: A field survey was conducted.

sen.j: 金昌洙「王仁出生地 霊岩郡」説を発表。
sen.e: Kim Chang Soo published the 'Yeongam County as Wani's birthplace' theory.
Kim Chang Soo published the 'Yeongam County as Wani's birthplace' theory.
Kim Chang Soo published the 'Yeongam County as Wani's birthplace' theory.

sen.j: 金昌洙「社団法人王仁博士顯彰協会創立」
sen.e: Kim Chang Soo established the 'Dr. Wani Commendation Association.'
Kim Chang Soo established the 'Dr. Wani Commendation Association.'
Kim Chang Soo established the 'Dr. Wani Commendation Association.'

sen.j: 1975年6月 金昌洙「博士王仁 日本に植えた韓国の精神」を出版。
sen.e: June, 1975: Kim Chang Soo published 'Dr. Wani: Korean Spirit that He Spread in Japan.'
June, 1975: Kim Chang Soo published 'Dr. Wani: Korean Spirit that He Spread in Japan.'
June, 1975: Kim Chang Soo published 'Dr. Wani: Korean Spirit that He Spread in Japan.'

sen.j: 全羅南道教育委員会 王仁博士 遺跡学術セミナー 開催
sen.e: The Cholla-namdo Education Committee held the 'Dr. Wani Remains Academic Seminar.'
The Cholla-namdo Education Committee held the 'Dr. Wani Remains Academic Seminar.'
The Cholla-namdo Education Committee held the 'Dr. Wani Remains Academic Seminar.'

sen.j: 1976年 全羅南道文化財委員会 王仁遺跡文化財指定調査報告書
sen.e: 1976: The Cholla-namdo Education Committee produced the report on the investigation of cultural property designation at the Wani remains.
1976: The Cholla-namdo Education Committee produced the report on the investigation of cultural property designation at the Wani remains.
1976: The Cholla-namdo Education Committee produced the report on the investigation of cultural property designation at the Wani remains.

sen.j: 全羅南道 王仁博士遺跡地 道文化財記念物20号とする。
sen.e: South Cholla Province designated the Dr. Wani remains as provincial cultural property No. 20.
South Cholla Province designated the Dr. Wani remains as provincial cultural property No. 20.
South Cholla Province designated the Dr. Wani remains as provincial cultural property No. 20.

sen.j: 「王仁博士遺墟碑」を現地に建立。
sen.e: The 'Monument of Dr. Wani's Remains' was established in the province.
The 'Monument of Dr. Wani's Remains' was established in the province.

sen.j: 日本武尊の王子武田王の墓と言われるもので、王仁とは無関係。
sen.e: It is believed to be the tomb of Takeda no Okimi (Prince Yamatotakeru's son) and has nothing to do with Wani.
